Exactly, Allan.  Equating "exclusively" with "primarily" is an assault on the English language--and further, so is equating primarily with 51 percent.  (Remember when Senator Cornyn, ?or Kyl?, said Planned Parenthood devoted over 90 percent of its business to abortion and he was only off by a factor of 8 or 9?)  Isn't this a case about tax avoidance that former Senator Moynihan called "defining deviancy down?"

As Lawrence O’Donnell has been saying since Monday, the so-called IRS scandal is only the consequence of an older and more basic problem with the organization’s reading of the tax code – specifically, with its reading of Section 501(c)(4), which exempts social welfare groups from paying taxes.

The law defines such groups as “civic leagues or organizations not organized for profit but operated exclusively for the promotion of social welfare.” Since 1959, the IRS has been reading “exclusively” as “primarily.”

No doubt, whoever was responsible for that change should be tried and jailed, except I think the statue of limitations has expired.

Being ignorant of the standard, it may be ridiculous to post this. But it would seem also that the provisions granted were intended to be extended to independent groups. It is their job to look for red flags and then take additional scrunity. Why wouldn't trained investigators perceive a flood of applications from a proliferation of groups as singularly focused as the tea party as part of an organized movement? An organized movement would suggest a hierachy with the potential for a corporate management with links to corporate interests that ought to be investigated to make sure that "social welfare" and not corporate profits are the organizations goal.

I'm not suggesting that an organization isn't entitled to tax exempt status under the provision, but that link must be investigated and cleared first before groups working under that organizations cover are similarly approved. It just makes good sense.

But then, I could be wrong...
Who, ultimately, gets to define social welfare? The problem is that one group's social welfare is another group's politicking.

@ Sallyb:

From Columbia Encyclopedia:
"SOCIAL WELFARE: Organized provision of educational, cultural, medical, and financial assistance to the needy. Modern social welfare measures may include any of the following: the care of destitute adults; the treatment of the mentally ill; the rehabilitation of criminals; the care of destitute, neglected, and delinquent children; the care and relief of the sick or handicapped; the care and relief of needy families; and supervisory, educational, and constructive activity, especially for the young."

Seems pretty straightforward. No politicking involved. Of course, tea party types would probably say liberals, progressives, and Democrats are "needy,"

OK, I see your point.

The mess appears not to be Congress's fault. That mess -- a murky set of qualifications for the holy grail of 501(c)(4) status, with no contribution limits, secrecy for donor's names and amounts, and very loose limits on what the cash is used for -- seems to have been born in the IRS, not in Congress.

The Congressional statute gave the exemption to non-profit organizations operated "exclusively" for the promotion of social welfare.

"Exclusively."

But IRS defined the "exclusive" requirement out of existence:
"[A]n organization is operated __exclusively_ for the promotion of social welfare if it is __primarily__ engaged in promoting in some way the common good and general welfare of the community." (Reg. 1. 501(c)(4)-1(a)(2)(i).)

That's no longer "exclusively", and therefore it's not a bright line, easily administered. "Primarily" means what? 51%? Of funds used? Of employee time? Of employee and volunteer time? Or even more subjective measures? Donor intent or affiliation?

So the IRS, facing a flood of applications after donor limits were removed by Citizens United, was left to decide them without coherent standards.

Little wonder some aggressive applications tried to game the system. And little wonder IRS employees tried to simplify the largely standardless determination by focussing on a few political key words (although the Cincinnati bunch plainly botched it, for lack of political sensitivity; I wonder if Washington hands might have been less tin-eared).

When an organization is delayed, asked foolish questions and management does nothing to correct it someone needs to correct the system, fire the guilty to prevent future issues.  Same as in the private sector.
